page.title: 02ATTENBOROUGH Gravel working.
page.content: DOWN THE GRAVEL PITS. At the end of the Strand in Attenborough, a small village on the Nottingham - Derbyshire border, there is 219 hectares of reclaimed gravel workings. The gravel from the river terraces has been in great demand since the first world war when the swampy area was used for growing reeds to make baskets for the shells produced at the local Ordnance Factory. The gravel has been extracted further and further away from the original working near the Long Lane processing plant and has now almost reached Long Eaton. The gravel is transported by barge from the workings to the processing plant and then by lorries which disturb the peace of Attenborough village.
